description.text: Used to add a power switch to the Natia i3ALD  Uses switch YRM32F2FBBNN from Mouser

Take one part Airtripper extruder and one part JohannRocholl Kossel Mini extruder. Mix them well and you end up with the SaldoT extruder. No additional parts should be needed than the ones that comes with a standard Kossel Mini kit that uses the BOM from the reprap wiki. I like airtrippers design but since it doesn't fit on a geared Nema 17 motor and requires a larger ball bearing then the one that came with my Kossel mini kit I decided to remix it and combine with Johann's extruder design. Note: This is for a geared Nema 17 motor like the one e3d sells; http://e3d-online.com/Electrical/Stepper-Motors/Geared-stepper-motor
For a normal Nema 17 I suggest airtrippers original extruder. Added holder for a geared Nema 17 holder. Baseplate is circular to allow for different mounting angles.

I suggest printing with support, 30% (or 50%) infill and 2 shell layers. Components needed besides the printed parts:
1x 625 ball bearing (5x16x5)
1x M5-0.8x20 Cap Screw
1x M5 Washer
4x M3-0.5x25 Cap Screw
2x M3-0.5x35 Cap Screw (or 2x M3-0.5x40 Cap Screw if using rubber hose for tension)
3x M3 Hex Nuts (Nylock optional)
4x M3 Washer All of these parts should come with a Kossel Mini Kit if it uses the extruder as listed in the reprap wiki. Usually only 3 M3x35 Cap Screws are needed to build the printer sp you should have 3 spare as most kit ship with 6 M3x35 Cap Screws. Optionally you can add a diesel hose for idler tensions as described by airtripper. If so you'll need longer screws for the idler and should replace 2x M3-0.5x35 Cap Screw with 2x M3-0.5x40 Cap Screw.

title: Straight Track Garden Railway System 45mm Gauge

description.text:
On public request comes track in 45mm gauge.
Straight track for 45mm gauge tracks , common used in Garden railways (16mm and LGB).
The length off the tracks are made so they are printable on most 3D-printers.
There are track holders for printed sleepers och wooden sleepers.
There are STL files for complete track, track you assemble by your self and complete track for dual extruder printers.
My goal is to release all track already released in 32mm gauge in 45mm gauge.

It should be easy to print this track, and you only need support on the complete tracks.
Dual extruder tracks aren't test printed yet, but seems Ok in Cura.
All STL files has been tested in Netfabb.
All "Dual" STL are for dual extruder print.
Template are for easy assembly.
I have printed my tracks with PLA at 0.3mm layer height and 30-50% infill. (30% is enough, 50% is on the safe side)

description.text: Draft of Assistive handles for arthritis, paralysis or injury that causes weakness in the hands. Use in combination with T-Handle or Ball-Handle (also in my things) for easy gripping for standard kitchen utensils like whisks, spatulas, serving spoons and more.

This is the mold for easy silicone casting of the T-handle. Print it and pour in food safe 2-part silicone like Smooth-On 940. You can print two and press them together for both halves or mold one side at a time and use the same silicone to weld them together. Fits handles with diameter of .8"-1.2" (20.5mm-30.5mm) Should be very snug so that it is stable. If necessary use soap to lubricate for initial installation. title: Ergonomic Stand for Macbook (Laptop) CNC/Cutting Tool-Path

description.text:
Simple stand to hold my MacBook Pro at eye-level when used for extended Making / Programming sessions.   (I do my best work outside)  
The stand was a sketching skill improvement experience for me, the goal was to make a compact stand that could be cut out with one pass/tool-path whereby the bit is often cutting both pieces at the same time.  This saves material and CNC time.

Fusion 360 Mill plan (gcode) available on request.   
Mainbody is cut from 3/4" stock (Bamboo in my case).  The shape is designed to achieve functional goal of raising MacBook (ok any laptop) height to eye level while also providing stability for occasional direct keyboard use (as in a kitchen / standing situation) as well as manufacturing optimization to reduce wasted wood.  
Cross brace is secured with wood screw and small washer.   and cut from same 3/4" stock.

title: Towel R/C Plane Motor Mount and Nose Plate

description.text: This is a redesigned motor mount for the Towel RC Plane. The drill pattern is for a tower pro 2108-21T brushless motor with 12mm center to center spacing. The holes are countersunk so the screws fit better and allow for a slightly thicker/stronger plate. The motor mount is designed similar to this thing, but technically not real remix of: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14507 Also shown is a front nose brace that is used to strengthen the front tip of the plane. The nose seemed to be the portion of the foam that got destroyed the fastest on the first build of this plane, so designed this to provide a bit of reinforcement without adding much weight. Although maybe that is not an issue for more experienced flyers that don't end up flying the plane nose first into the ground! The plane was covered with red packing/sealing tape to give everything the bright red coloring you see in the pics. It is a great look compared to the naked foam used in the first build. On the second build of this plane, shown in the pics, we also used these servo horns, they worked great and much better than the non-printed servo horns made out of coroplast that we used in the first build: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:46620 The design instructions can be found here: http://makezine.com/projects/make-30/the-towel-rc-stunt-plane/ and even more info is also here: (they now call it the flack. http://www.brooklynaerodrome.com

author: AcademyFab

title: Quad motor skid for 22xx and 18xx size motors!

description.text:
Mount under motors to stop damage when the quad slides along on hard surfaces. 19x12 for 3mm screws for larger motors. 16x12 for 2mm 1806 and similar motors.
Added 14mm high version for Nighthawk.

Use a setting that gives a strong bond, I use .25mm and a reasonably fine hex pattern internally.  
Motor screws go through skid, use a little Loctite to hold the motor in place, do not overtighten, the screws only need to be firm to hold the motor in place. The inset is 2mm so you will need 2mm longer screws, make sure you check that the screws do not go through the motor casing and damage the windings, screws should not need to screw in to the motor more than 2mm, if they are any longer get shorter ones or cut them off. For a 2204 motor and 3mm thick arm you should use 7mm screws, 8mm should also be fine but check the clearance.

description.text:
This Dalek model is derived from guydebored's models. I wanted to print a larger sized Dalek on my TOM, so I sliced up the model, but I didn't want to glue the pieces together.  
I've always wanted to connect split up parts with a pin connector, so this is the first time I've tried something like that. I used the PLA Cube Gears as a template for creating my pins and sockets.  
The added benefit of using the pins is that each section, including the head can spin.  
The models, especially the bottom part, aren't perfect, but I've ran them through netfabbcloud, and they slice and print without any issues.

Head - Print at 5% infill, 2 shells (increase to 3 if gap near top of head)
Middle - Print at 5% infill, 2 shells, external supports
Bottom - Print at 5% infill, 1 shell
Weapons - Print with 50% infill, 1 shell, external supports, print slow!
Pins - Print with 25% infill, 1 shell The middle part really should use full supports, but the mess after cleanup was just as bad as only using external supports. As long as your printer can bridge decently, there should only be a few dangling strings to clean up. If your bot is carefully calibrated, supports printed at .50 flow rate will peel right off with your fingers. I've had no problem removing any supports structures, even from the delicate weapon parts.

description.text: Just a piece for a 50-year old intercom system in my house.

This is basically just a costume piece. It is a wearable monocle with a functioning iris mechanism. It also has mounts on the front for three LEDs if you want to add some lights. I think it looks awesome with UV LEDs and red fluorescent ABS plastic. I will upload the Google Sketchup files for all of these later when I have some more time. I drew inspiration for the iris mechanism from this source:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Paper-Mechanical-Iris/ Here are some videos of it in action:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hvi482_4f5w
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T0X-w5Whook

You can either build the entire monocle, or just the iris mechanism if you want.  The only difference is that if you just want to test out the iris mechanism you don't print the monocle piece.  This thing goes together in what you could call layers.  You sort of sandwich the parts together.
1) Print RingWHolesAndMount.stl
2) Print 6 of the FlapWstub file.  I have included FlapWstubX3 so you can print three in one print if you want.  However you do it, you need 6 in total.
3) You need to attach the flaps to the RingWHolesAndMount.  They attach to the side that does not have the LED mounts.  You need to use small screws that have low profile heads.  I used #4-40 1/2" machine screws I bought from Home Depot.  Insert the screws so the heads are against the flap and the screw pokes out of the ring.  The flaps have little pegs that need to be facing away from the ring.
4) Once all of the flaps are attached, arrange them so they are flush with the ring.  Each flap should go on top of the next one, all the way around.
5) Now take the monocle piece and thread four larger screws through the four mounting holes.  You want the screws to poke out away from the person who will be wearing this thing.  This step is optional.  If you just want a working iris mechanism to play with and don't want to print the monocle, you can just skip this step.
6) Print TestingRing.stl.  You may have to clean up the circular slot so there are no strings inside.  Strings will make the mechanism rotate poorly.
7) Slide the TestingRing onto all four screws.  The side that has the circular slot needs to face away from the monocle.  Slide the TestingRing down so it is flat against the monocle.
8) Print RingWithSlots.stl.  Again, clean up the slots so everything will slide nice and easily.
9) Slide RingWithSlots onto all four screws so the pegs fit into the circular slot on the TestingRing.  The slots on the RingWithSlots should be facing away from the monocle.
10) Slide the RingWHolesAndMount onto all four mounting screws.  Make sure the flaps are sandwiched between the rings.  As you slide this ring on, rotate the flaps so their pegs fit into the slots on the RingWithSlots.  If they seem too large to fit, you may have to file/sand them down so they fit in.
11) Print Spring.stl.
12) Slide one spring onto each of the mounting screws.  These springs provide constant pressure to the outer ring.  When you rotate the RingWithSlots, the flaps press against each other and the outer ring wants to be pushed out.  These springs allow the ring to move outward, but also move back inward.  They aren't strictly needed but they help the mechanism work a lot more smoothly.
13) Place a nut on each mounting screw and screw it down so there is slight pressure on each spring.
You should be done now.  The RingWithSlots is the one that you rotate manually.  There is a small nub sticking off of the side that you can grab onto and use to rotate the ring.  If it isn't working correctly, make sure all of flaps have their pegs sitting in the slots on the RingWithSlots.  Slowly rotate the RingWithSlots and make sure that none of the flap pegs are falling out.
If you want to mount LEDs on this, you can slide them into the LED mounts on the outermost ring.  I used 5mm LEDs and had to carve out a bit of the mounts in order to get them to fit.  They fit nice and snug now.  I wired them up in series and have a small 2AA battery mount taped into the side of the monocle.  There is plenty of room for it in there.  I might modify the monocle to include a holder for the batteries, I just don't want to do another 3 hour print.
For a strap, I used a pilates resistance band and just cut it to size with scissors.  Then I tied it to the monocle piece where the band slots are.  It seems to work well, although it has a very distinct rubber smell.

comments.text: This is HUGE (close to 4" scross) in its original size, I printed it our pretty successfully at 75%, 50% is too small for the mechanical parts to function, but it would work for a non moving prop (50% is a good size as a monocle)  I'm doing a 66%  now to see if that will retain functionality.

Since we've started using acceleration, there hasn't really been an accurate way of calculating how long a print is going to take until you do it. The RepRap host software averages how long each line of Gcode takes as the build is running, and then extrapolates it over the entire build. The problem with this is it takes a long time to get an accurate average, and also the top of parts tend to have shorter lines than the bottom - leading to inaccuracies. This is a simple java program to estimate how long the gcode will take to run, taking into account accelerations. Thus far it only calculates the time for all G1 and G28 moves, but this is the vast majority.
The reason for starting this is I've been trying to tune my slicing preferences to optimise build speeds, but its unclear exactly how much I'm gaining without doing the print first. Also often I've found the sacrifice in quality just isn't worth the time benefit. Thus far its a little quick and dirty. Its tried and tested with RepRap 5D style acceleration but should also be compatible with the new caruKlip accel too; you just need to tell the software which you are using in the parameters section of the code I've done a few tests and thus far its always been accurate to within a few minutes P.S. Be gentle, I'm not a programmer :D
Edit the java to enter your parameters and edit the line defining the location of the gcode. Compile and run in a terminal window.

description.text: Prevents your u-lock from being stolen while you are riding
Update: Check out the customizable version

A mount for u-locks on bikes. Provides a lot of settings to fit on your bike and lock.
Contains OpenSCAD-files to manipulate the model.
If you print it I would be very happy to see some pictures!

The idea to this model is based on this instructable
Shoutouts to
Uniq for helping me printing and providing the printer
Emi for these artistic fotos
Metalab for being such a cool hackerspace ;-)

[2013-05-12] UPDATE
I rounded the edges where the lock slides through. This should make it easier to mount and remove the lock.
The downside is, that rendering now takes significantly longer.
The version with sharp edges is in lockholder_fast_and_easy(v_1_0).scad, the new version is in lockholder.scad.

What you need
  • A bike and a u-lock (well, that's obvious)
  • A 3D-Printer (probably you wouldn't be here otherwise)
  • 8 equal screws (should be a bit longer than twice the thickness of your print - I would recommend 1 - 2 cm)
  • 8 equal nuts fitting on your screws
    How to build it
    1. Download the model (especially lockholder.scad and makeLockholder.scad). The *.stl files are based on my bike. You probably won't need them as it is unlikely that your bike and lock has the same dimensions as mine.
    2. Measuring
      • Measure the diameter of your bike's top tube (or another round tube where you want to mount the lock
      • Measure the diameter of your u-lock. As you will later slide the u-lock through the holder, measure the thickest area of the u-part of the lock.
      • Measure the diameter of your nuts (if you were laughing now, please grow up). Measure the flat size (look here: Wikipedia: Nut, measure A/F)
      • Measure the diameter of your screw's thread
    3. Now start OpenSCAD. Edit the file makeLockholder.scad (Instead you could also open a new file and import the lockholder functions with include </path/to/lockholder.scad>;). The previous version of the lockholder has sharper edges (which maybe makes sliding the lock inside slightly more difficult) but renders much faster. If you prefer this version, use include </path/to/lockholder_fast_and_easyv_1_0.scad>; instead.
    4. Use one of the functions lockHolderSet() or completeLockHolderSet() first. Insert your measures from above. Depending on your printer you should add a bit of spacing to some of the settings, as otherwise some holes might be to tight. I added 0.5 mm to diameterTopTube and 1 mm to diameterLock, nutSizeOuter and nutSizeInner. It depends on your printer if you would like to add a bit more or less.
    5. For most situations it's a good idea to print all parts seperately (besides other advantages you can abort misprints easier like this). To do so, first print a bottom part, than a top part and if it fits repeat. Therefore if the output in OpenSCAD looks alright, now replace the function you used with bottomPart. Leave the parameters as they are. After printing the first bottom part, replace the function with topPart.
    6. Compile and render the model (F6-button), and export to a format you can further process for printing.
    7. Print it (you are on your own with this step)
    8. To mount the printed parts, use the screws and nuts. The offset between the two lockholders can be determined easiest when you fix one lockholder on your bike and slide the lock through it.

      Description for lockholder.scad
      Four main modules are provided

      • topPart() Top part of the lockholder
      • bottomPart() Bottom part of the lockholder
      • lockHolderSet() A set of 1 top part and 1 bottom part
      • completeLockHolderSet() A set of 2 top parts and 2 bottom parts
        Each of these functions takes all of these parameters
  • diameterTopTube The diameter of your bike's top tube (or any other tube on which you want to mount the lockholder)
  • lengthLock Length of the tube where you put the lock through. The longer the less vibrations while riding. On the other hand, if the the tube gets too long it might be clumsy
  • diameterLock Diameter of the lock (this will be the inner diameter of the part that holds the lock)
  • nutSizeOuter The outer diameter of your hexagonal screw nut A/F here
  • nutSizeInner Diameter of your screw thread
  • thickness Material thickness
  • offset Offset between upper and lower part of the lockholder. The bigger this value is, the tighter you can screw the lockholder on your bike. However, if offset is getting too big, the material might break while fastening the screw. Normally the lockholders arc would bend down a bit anyway while printing. In this case you can relax and set this value to zero. Otherwise you might want to set it to 1 or 2 mm. If you don't understand the purpose of this variable, try setting it to a large fraction of diameterTopTube and check the result - then you will probably understand it.
  • screwOffsetShare This value allows to master the thickness of the screwholes as a share of . At 1, there is no difference to normal thickness, at 0 there is no material to fix the screw. To be on the save side this should be 1 or not too much lower than 1.

description.text:
Grow a rose plant inside a rose pot!  
Print one as a Mother's day Gift!  
Please share if you print one!

Print with at least 2 layer walls and 40% infil for strength. Raft would be very nice because it can easily be tipped by the printer due to its shape. Use 1mm excess raft. The pot itself does not need support. The dish will need support. Choose your own layer height, however I found 0.2mm to be more than sufficient (still took me 18 hours to print with at 145% scaling) Edit (08/05/2015):
  • changed the STL to utilize a rose designed by XYZWorkshop because it has thicker petals (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:152642)
  • adjusted the height of the walls to interfere less with the aesthetics
  • added a small recess to the dish for water to puddle before flowing off the dish.
  • removed the file without walls because who wants a pot that doesnt contain the soil.

author: Quim

description.text:
I had some v-slot laying around so I tried to build a side table. Instead of ordering more parts, I 3d Printed new parts to help put the thing together since I didn't want to order in more parts.  
Since 3mm nuts fit perfectly inside the vslot, I used that as a base to making a tee nut. From there I made corner wedges and corner plates along with two types of tees.  
Big shout out to  Bobnet, his v-slot caps made it easy to built these bits since I was able to his stl as a starting point in terms of measurements and shapes. Saved me lots of trial and error I normally would have to do.  
Freecad available for anyone who wants to make more vslot parts.

description.text:
Main Project Page - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668017 Working on an arduino project and Kinda wished I had a rig for testing. So I designed a simple rig concept with plates that can be tied together using quarter inch parts. Current Plates
  • Arduino UNO R3 with spacers. Just need some 3mm screws about 10mms long to keep it on the plate.
  • Breadboard, it has sliding holes so you can probably hold more then a breadboard. But I designed this plate to hold a standard and mini breadboard.
  • Holes, This one is more specific to my current project where I want to use an articulated arm to hold my prop up while Wiring everything.
  • Standard, for anyone who wants to poke custom holes in for any specific task you need.
    • You don't really need the qInch Cubes to create the rig, but i used them to try out different rig ideas. One such idea is a multi level rig by using the cubes to build upward. For now I'm sticking with the carrying tray layout I have now. Video of the rig in action.

author: nicolasperalta

title: Kcs low power electrical push push switch

description.text:
This low power electrical switch is part of a reading lamp that I'm designing. My design goals are:
  • no vitamins (i.e. completely printable except cables/electrics/electronics)
  • easy printing (avoiding excessive overhangs, etc.)
  • easy assembly
    • I wanted to make an electrical switch with push push mechanism, similar to the ones that are known from ball pens, but completely printable. This is the result of several weeks of design, trial, error and redesign. The main idea is to have two cable ends connected and separated inside the mechanism, so it will propably only be save for real low power applications (like powering a LED). The mechanism is complete except the part that connects the cables. Update 2013-05-02:
    Yesterday, I tested if the switch will still work after longer activation time. I set it to "on" (springs in compressed state) and let it in this position over night. Unfortunately, the big spring seems to have permanently deformed over this time and can't get back to full decompression, so the switch is stuck :( Seems I will have another try at this one... propably more space and a longer spring will do, but I want to check other options first.

Print each of the STLs once. I printed PLA with 0.2mm layer height and 0.55 mm extrusion width on a 0.5mm nozzle.
Maybe you will have to make the two springs in separate prints, because they tend to come of the bed when the nozzle moves over to another part. Check the video for a general idea how to assemble. Clean up the pin and the tracks on the labyrinth part so that the pin can move easily like shown in the video. Turn the pin by 90 degrees, stick it through the bottom of the spring box and turn it back so it is aligned to its track in the labyrint part. Attach the spring box onto the labyrinth but keep sure that the pin is not jammed. Put the small spring into the bigger tray of the spring box, right beneath the bar that separates the two trays. Put the separator over the small spring and the bar, so they are pushed against each other. Put the big spring between the separator and the pin. Attach the top lid. Enjoy :)

author: KidCrazy

description.text:
This mount holds the following: -2 watt laser diode http://www.ebay.com/itm/2W-445nm-M-Type-M140-Blue-Laser-Diode-In-Copper-Module-W-Leads-/170955273487?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item27cdba750f
(Optics) http://www.ebay.com/itm/260684420819?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
-Laser diode driver http://www.ebay.com/itm/181657463022?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
-80mm PC fan The mounting holes are for two M3 screws, 30mm apart. They will hopefully screw into your extruder stepper. (It may not fit to your specific extruder setup) The mount obviously needs to be pulled tight against your extruder setup in order to get crisp precise results. The system runs directly off of my 12v PSU (with an added inline switch). I also use stripped stranded copper wire as a poor-man's heatsink for the diode. It works very well. "WOOD BURNER.ini" is the cura settings that I use when running the laser engraver. Safety Glasses to protect your retinas: http://www.ebay.com/itm/Laser-Protection-Goggles-Safety-Glasses-Green-Blue-405nm-445nm-450nm-532nm-/321674344590?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item4ae548f88e NOTE: The diode driver can very quickly burn out the laser diode (in seconds) if the current/voltage is set too high. Use a multimeter to make sure the output voltage and current of the driver are not set too high. (4.25 volts and 1.8 amps is ideal for a 2 watt diode) Testing the current requires a load on the driver, such as the diode itself, so start at the lowest power output and work your way up while monitoring the multimeter. The chosen driver also features TTL (digital ON/OFF via PIN outputs) and PWM (digital "throttling" of the diode). But I am still searching for a free and effective software solution to generate g-code for this purpose. Using Cura and "Printing" as if it were 3d-printing has worked very well for black-and-white style images, but I have had difficulty getting good grayscale results so far.

comments.text: Question: how did you connect the laser's TTL input? Or are you using another method to switch off and on the laser?
comments.author: Finch666

comments.text: The fan output off of your board. Although cura won't be able to incorporate this into the g-code (the laser runs as always on). To fully use TTL, you need this software http://jtechphotonics.com/?product=piclaser-photo-engraving-sw-license
comments.author: Finch666

comments.text: Hi, what software are you using to laser the designs? Im looking for a gcode gerator that can work with my existing 3d printer infrastructure.
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: I used cura, using the settings in the WOOD BURNER.ini file located on this page. Make sure whatever you are engraving is only 1-2 layers. Unfortunately it doesn't work well for grayscale images.

I cleaned up a scanned Funko POP and decided to try to make a blank model that people can customize. This model still could use some work, but this is the best I could do. This would be amazing if someone could edit this with OpenSCAD so this could be used with customizer. mothers day cake toper

This Eggbot has mechanical Parts, that are mostly made of Fischer Technik (FT).
Fischer Technik is a typical german Toy. See
http://www.fischertechnik.de/en/desktopdefault.aspx
I like it very much, because one can design quickly mechanics or little machines like this one. This Eggbot is a drivat of SphereBot by Zaggo
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7656
All the Electronics and Software are the same, except of the reference sensor. Still now i easily dont use it.

Hopefully the pictures will explain what to do, but feel free to contact me for furhter informations.
I had only some problems to solve the machanical Interfaces to the Steppermotors. FT use axes with a diameter of 4mm, but the Stepper have 5mm or M5. Sure you can drill it with 5mm, but i dont like to "damage" my FT-parts.
Also the NEMA-Size is not typical for FT. So I made some plates that are "compatible".
For this it is good to use an cnc.

This is a second proof of concept for a plinth to mount 3D models that is mostly cuboid in shape, but should be much less prone to curling up at the corners. This is particularly an issue when printing cuboids, which can make printing a model of a building challenging. The idea is simple: to reduce the length of any straight sections, where the force exerted by cooling and contracting filament can build up, which is most extreme at the corners and in the first few layers. It's a customizable design, so you can create the size of base plate you need to mount your model. This is an initial concept I had, there is much more to come around use of texture to prevent warping of models. Please share your makes and give attribution, as well as feedback! A few notes:
Firstly, the goal here is to establish how best the design itself can reduce curl-up, all other factors being equal. NOT to solve curl-up by any means. I use a range of printers and materials, and am aware of other ways to make things stick. Secondly, the principle should apply to all thermoplastics which contract on extrusion. Thirdly, to clarify what the object is - it's designed to be a part of the model - a plinth on which you would place a cuboid model such as a house, with long straight sides which might otherwise experience some curling at sharp corners.

Revised: 12-14-15
  • Reduced the radius at the outside bottom of the tray. Cleaned up the print in that area.
  • Added finger clearance holes to make opening easier.
  • Added clearance in the hinge area so the box closes better.
    • Also found a jumbo paper clip makes a great hinge rod. Push it through, make a short bend in the end, pull tight to part, bend other end and clip off excess as close to the hinge as possible. 120 mm Square parts tray that folds in half to keep parts in. Used a piece of 14 AWG copper wire as a hinge. Takes a bit of work to thread the wire.

Not a serious offering for a new royal birth souvenir, but a quick technical challenge to 3d print a Lithophane image via desk top 3D printing. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qZRzFZ9A7YI Interestingly, this technique of creating an image by varying the thickness of material so when backlit produces a photographic representation was popular when the new princesses, great, great, great grandmother was on the throne. Now created using a modern day technology. Came out pretty well! Interest on the internet as well:
http://3dprint.com/63528/royal-baby-princess-charlotte/ Enjoy!

description.text:
A simple docking station for an Arduino, designed for Decemillia. Use this to protect your Arduino from metal surfaces (short-circuit!) and other hazards.
Also useful to quickly (de-)attach the brain of a project (Arduino) so you can have multiple projects using the same Arduino.

Laser cut in 3 mm plexiglass (PMMA). Mount both large pieces at right angles. Use glue if you so desire. The smaller snaphooks in the file were a test - these will not work. I'll upload a newer version utilizing a screw soon.
Mount the dock with hotglue, ducttape, etc. to whatever you want it attached to.

title: Cutaway, Hollow Elements
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A collection of pieces for building polyhedral shells. Derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5961. The original pieces took a while to print. This version reduces plastic, and therefore print time. I've been using these pieces to print out lamp-shades ( with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7857 ). The thinner pieces might be a bit better for diffusing light. The .scad file can be modified to produce different polygons, different sizes of hinge, and different depths of cutaway. models.zip contains several pieces :
-- octagon, hexagon, pentagon, square, triangle
-- hollow and cutaway
-- a range of hinge sizes depending on shape size to adjust hinge strength The good :
-- less plastic
-- faster prints
-- symmetric hinges
-- range of hinge sizes to balance strength and ease of assembly
-- fun with glow-in-the-dark ABS : https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/_KLnvj61OxTo/Tbh6JxKqlkI/AAAAAAAACqc/RJWNnHgdTYo/DSCF2997.gif The bad :
-- fragile hinges ( depending on printer calibration )
-- overly tight hinges ( depending on printer calibration )
-- large force required to assemble larger hinges

I print on a heated build platform with no raft to keep the parts clean, at 235C for the first layers and then 220C extruder temperature for the rest of the print, and 123C for the heated build platform. I also adjust the skeinforge profile until the hinges are double-walled with minimal infill. Properly calibrated oozebane ( or a stepper extruder ) is essential, as strings would make the hinges take forever to clean. After printing, trim off the extra plastic that stabilizes the hinges. After this, I 'loosen up' the hinges a bit by snapping two pieces together and bending them back and forth several times. This tends to dislodge most stray plastic, or at least make it clear where you need to trim. The larger hinges are quite strong but hard to snap together. I use a pair of needle-nose pliers to add force. Some polyhedral shells are very difficult to assemble in the end, and pieces with smaller hinges might be easier to insert in this case. When building lampshades with Element http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7857, I leave the bulb socket holder for last, since it is more flexible and easier to insert. note on hinge clearance : The hinges can sometimes be a little tight. Make sure the first layer isn't pressed too far into the build platform. A compressed first layer will propagate up and make part of the hinge wider, decreasing the clearance. These parts are designed to fit tightly and may require pliers to assemble. If all else fails, removing some of the pins on the hinges can make assembly easier.

comments.text: Printed it out on a MakerBot Replicator 2 with PLA.  Pieces printed great.  Can't fit them together.
comments.author: cpettis

comments.text: Yes, this is a known issue. The pieces were designed to fit as tightly as possible using ABS. ABS is more elastic and so can tolerate more deformation of the hinges when snapping together. You will need to increase the hinge spacing, and decrease the elevation of the "nubs" on the hinges, in order to get something that will work with PLA.
comments.author: cpettis

author: mrule

description.text:
Slim potentiometer knobs.
This was made to imitate some missing knobs from a LeCroy oscilloscope. It fits nicely on a 1/4 inch potentiometer D-shaped shaft. I have put up a few slight permutations: Single piece, Base and cap two-part (for a two-color print) and Core and Ring (also two-color print). The idea of the two-color prints is that you can color-code them. I have printed them all out on a Replicator 2X in ABS (the two-color in natural and antistatic filament) and they come out dimensionally ok, but the two-color prints are a little messy on the 2X. I found the antistatic ABS needed a lower bed temperature, as it was pliable when I printed it, and set up out-of-shape. Ten seconds in the microwave, however, and it was pliable enough to stretch over the potentiometer shaft.

As messy as a two-color print turned out when I printed this, if you are going to print multiple color combinations, I would recommend just printing the solid version and changing filaments mid-print, unless you actually need a different core material.  Printed with standard settings on a Makerbot Replicator 2X.  It's a small print, so you might as well use file layer height.  Use at least two shells and I recommend about 25% fill.

comments.text: You CAN, but they would be very weak and fragile... IIRC m3 washers are only 1mm thick, so even if you printed at 0.2mm layer height, they would only be 5 layers thick. Quite weak. comments.text: "Parametric" usually means you can alter the parameters of the object. This is an STL of a egg design. Nice, but not remotely parametric.
comments.author: donstratton

comments.text: Hi, sorry for the late reply, I've just discovered your comment. Actually, an .stl file cannot be parametric, so you've been right; but I designed this 3D model fully parametric with generative algorithms in Grasshopper, as you can see it in the linked tutorial, where you can adjust all the parameters (thickness, subdivision resolution, smoothing, etc.) with numeric sliders or even with a leap motion controller or your phone or kinect. If you are interested, I could send you the original grasshopper definition to create the geometry you want. peace ;)

See how it's been designed and 3D modeled: http://parametric-art.com/2013/04/03/generativ-husveti-tojasok-3d-nyomtatassal/ I also made a tutorial in english (sorry for grammar mistakes;)): http://3dprinted.tumblr.com/post/47184573851/3d-printed-generative-easter-eggs And last but not least I captured a stop-motion video as well: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RKgIYwXD3Iw Have fun! peace;)

author: bonooobong

description.text:
Customise then print these and stick them on your keyboard. Patterns and spacings on V2.2 from Marburg Medium braille font standard.
~see instructions~ Please provide suggestions for improvements. Next version to include better dot height functionality. v2.3 - 23 July 2015
Added Braille Scale Multiplier to increase braille size. v2.2 - 7th May 2015
Made Customisable The scad file has a matrix of all the braille letters that you can use in your own project if you wish (to save you from having to make them yourself)

For best results open in OpenSCAD, instructions - https://youtu.be/cukWgTyvWNs CUSTOMIZER_V2.3.scad
Current Thingiverse Customizer version
The most up-to-date version, tweak the settings yourself. Based on braille worldwide medical standards http://www.pharmabraille.com/ Default size is at minimum key size, you will likely want to increase this. • Use "Text Drop Down Box Select sets" to create stls of specific character sets (all,alphabetic,numeric,symbols,functions,commands) due to the complicated operations thingiverse might have problems rendering the whole set at once. • The main settings to modify are Base Height, Key Size & Braille Scale. • If you want to customise this more, all the braille settings regarding spacing and dot height are accessible if you download the scad file and open it directly in OpenSCAD. You can eliminate rendering problems on thingiverse by using OpenSCAD also. braille_allKeys_v2.2.stl
default settings, $fn=21
All V2.2 keys. Warning these are at the minimum possible size. use customiser to increase to the size of your keyboard keys in mm. /////////////// OLD STUFF LEFT HERE JUST BECAUSE ////////
OLD WAYS :(
brailleOpenSCAD_v1.zip
Contains the following 3 OpenSCAD files to create higher quality custom tiles (using Braille Normal font). Along with the original Customer version: customisable_brailleKeys_v1.1.scad
This one uses thingiverse's built in "write/braille.dxf" font which is lower resolution and only supports alphanumeric & symbols.

comments.text: The default .stl printed out okish on a Replicator 2 with PLA, high settings (0.1mm layer height). Took 1hr. Cobwebbing was a big issue since the bumps were so small and so closely spaced, even after tediously snipping off as much of the cobwebs as possible, it left some of the bumps unpleasantly rough. Also, someone who is blind might have trouble distinguishing the bumps from each other since the cobwebbing made some of the bumps fuse together slightly. Tweaking the temperature/retraction settings might help. And like the author said, the default keys ARE small, it probably would have helped to print it out as large as your keyboard can take it. It might have come out better to print the keys standing up for detail's sake since the Replicator 2 has higher precision xy than z, but that leads to its own problems like you would need a raft and it would multiply the print time even more.
comments.author: FuzzBot

comments.text: Thanks for your comments!   I will re-do the code for these to allow for greater control over glyph size and height in approximately one month.   I am currently doing a large paid project and I have no time to correct these issues presently.   Rest assured I value your comments and will work hard to provide something more usable.
comments.author: FuzzBot

comments.text: Cool idea! I work at a library and often get visually-impaired people needing help with the computers. I like the idea of being able to print custom braille keyboard covers, especially since it only uses about ~$0.80 worth of PLA. I'll give it a try to print in clear so that people that can see can still see the keys under the covers and use it too. If there is anyone who reads braille, I'd be curious to know how easy it is to read the braille keyboard cover.
comments.author: FuzzBot

comments.text: The braille is now scalable.  I suggest downloading the scad file and loading it in OpenSCAD to render all keys at once. Thingiverse Customiser fails due to the high numbers of operations in this file.  Use the Sets dropdown to render only certain keys at a time if using customiser to minimise failures.
comments.author: FuzzBot

author: NonsenseNikki

title: Sharpie holder for solidoodle 3 with Lawsy's replacement extruder

description.text: This is a slightly altered version of lasernipples' pencil holder. It still has the attachment the same, as it fits perfectly into lawsy's extruder for the solidoodle 3 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47561) but I've stretched the hole so it holds a sharpie. There are two files. The first one holds the end part of a sharpie, and the other holds the main body, in case you need more reach. Between the two of them, they also hold a lot of common pens. A little set screw might well allow other sizes of pen to be added pretty easily too. These come out as non manifold, as I've not prettified up all the faces, but they seem to slice ok for me. I've printed both out. See 'instructions' for more details.

All these print fine with no support. I use ABS.  
I printed these with a view to using my solidoodle as a plotter. This opens up a whole new wealth of possibilities. You can use multiple coloured pens and overdraw images, or turn complex pictures into vector drawings.  
I plan on using this to plot PCB designs directly onto photosensitive board avoiding the need to print out on pricey transparancies.

title: Dual Hot Show Mount For DSLR Camera

description.text:
My first creation I made a month or so back. Needed to be able to mount my mic and led light or mic and led screen. I use it on my Canon t3i but it should be compatible with Nikon DSLR cameras as well.   
I printed with PLA 100% infill and I used supports just for the part that connects to the camera. Pretty happy with the end result works great for what I needed.

comments.text: Would be great if you could make some kind of screwable connection to the camera hot shoe.

This bracelet uses 2 prints combined. The first print is of the core, made using a flex filament, which then slots into the second print made using a stronger material.

Okay, so, first off print the soft band.  
Second, switch filaments and start the hard beads.  
Third, pause the beads print at right around 5mm (will vary depending on your layer height) and place the soft band into the bead print.  
Fourth, resume the print.  
Enjoy!
